analysis.raw_analysis:
- Puzzle type: input = output; sizes unchanged (10x10, 8x8, 14x14).
- Visual Ex1: isolated 2-cell objects of colors 1 & 6 are flipped in-place (horiz/vert); other marks unchanged.
- Visual Ex2: same — 1&6 occur as 2-cell pairs and their two cells are inverted.
- Visual Ex3: same global rule on 1&6 pairs.
- Grid Ex1: bg=8; objects = connected size-2 {1,6}; op = swap the two cells (1↔6).
- Grid Ex2: bg=8; same swap on each 2-cell {1,6}; color 7 unchanged.
- Grid Ex3: bg=8; same swap on each 2-cell {1,6}; 7 unchanged.

=== INPUT-INPUT COMPARISONS ===
**Key insights only (2-3 bullet points max):**
- Inputs share sparse background (color 8) with small 2-cell objects made of color 1 and color 6 (horizontal or vertical).
- Object placements differ but object shapes/adjacencies are consistent → rule is local to each 1–6 object.

=== OUTPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
**Key insights only (2-3 bullet points max):**
- All outputs preserve background and other colors (color 7, color 8).
- Every connected 2-cell object of color 1+6 has its two cells swapped.

=== INPUT-OUTPUT COMPARISONS ===
- Ex1: each adjacent 1–6 pair inverted in place.
- Ex2: same — horizontal/vertical 1–6 pairs swapped.
- Ex3: same — all adjacent 1–6 pairs swapped.

=== COLOR REFERENCE ===
- color 1 ⇄ color 6 swapped; color 7 and color 8 unchanged.

- 5. Reference objects:
  - Background = color 8 and scattered singletons color 7 remain static.
  - Key refs = distinct 2-cell connected objects made of colors {1,6}.

- 6. Whole-grid patterns:
  - Sparse color-8 field with isolated 1/6 pairs and occasional color-7 singles.
  - Only the 1/6 pairs are transformed; other colors/positions unchanged.

- 7. Object analysis:
  - Most important objects = 2-cell {1,6} pairs.
  - Recurring transformation = in-place swap of the two colors (flip pair order).

=== GENERAL RULE ===
Identify every connected two-cell object composed exactly of the colors 1 and 6 (adjacent horizontally or vertically). For each such 1–6 pair, swap the colors of the two cells in place (the cell that was 1 becomes 6 and the cell that was 6 becomes 1), keeping the object’s position and orientation unchanged. Apply this swap independently to every such pair across the grid. All other cells (including background color 8 and any singletons or other colors such as 7) remain unchanged.

general_steps.instruction: Step 1: for each (every connected two-cell object composed exactly of the colors 1 and 6, adjacent horizontally or vertically) A, perform transition color_mapping
general_steps.condition: Every distinct connected region of size 2 whose two cells are the colors {1,6} (horizontal or vertical). For each such object, swap the colors of the two cells in place (the cell that was color 1 becomes color 6 and the cell that was color 6 becomes color 1). All other cells (including colors 7 and 8 and any singletons) remain unchanged.

steps.instruction: CROP: Object 2 (Two horizontally adjacent cells at row 2 cols 0-1 (cells with colors 1 and 6))
steps.substep_reasoning: Cropping to object 2 to apply color_mapping transformation. Bbox: [2, 0, 2, 1]

steps.instruction: TRANSFORM: Object 2 (color_mapping)
steps.substep_reasoning: Applying color_mapping to object 2 based on condition: Every distinct connected region of size 2 whose two cells are the colors {1,6} (horizontal or vertical). For each such object, swap the colors of the two cells in place (the cell that was color 1 becomes color 6 and the cell that was color 6 becomes color 1). All other cells (including colors 7 and 8 and any singletons) remain unchanged.

steps.instruction: UNCROP: Object 2 back to full grid
steps.substep_reasoning: Placing transformed object 2 back into full grid at bbox [2, 0, 2, 1]
